_prev_prog_3.Description:
Ammonia Process



In November 2011, the anhydrous ammonia tank was replaced with a new smaller tank, almost a third of the size of the previous tank.  



The ammonia neutralization process is a batch process in which acids are neutralized with anhydrous ammonia (NH3) in an atmospheric tank with agitator (blend tank) or a pressure vessel (reactor). The ammonia flow to the reactors and blend vessels is controlled so that almost all of the ammonia is absorbed.  Any excess ammonia is vented to the plant thermal oxidizer, where it is burned. Safety relief devices are installed on the reactor to prevent catastrophic failure of the reactor should an unlikely over-pressurization occur. Over-pressurization is not possible on the atmospheric tanks, so no relief system is necessary on the blend vessels.



Ammonia is stored onsite in a 265 psig rated pressure vessel. The ammonia tank is equipped with pressure relief valve, all outlets on the tank have an excess flow valve combination, and there is an excess flow valve on the line to the plant.   All pressure relief valve and excess flow valves are on a regular PM schedule.  Check valves are also installed at the vessel to prevent backflow of potential contaminants to the storage vessel.  The ammonia tank is equipped with a high and high high level alarm.  The tank is inspected by a third party for external once every five years and internal once every ten years.  Perimeter monitoring alarms are installed on all four sides of the tank.



The loading of the storage tank from a delivery truck is accomplished by use of a closed loop vapor recycle system in which the vapor ammonia is pumped from the top of the tank truck by a compressor to the bottom of the storage tank, and the ammonia vapor from the top of the storage tank is recycled back to the tank truck so that no ammonia is exhausted to the atmosphere. The plant operator and truck driver manage the following: the connection of the truck to the storage vessel, the unloading of the truck, and the uncoupling of the truck from the storage tank. The plant operators and truck drivers have been trained and are experienced in the safe handling of ammonia.  There is a written ammonia unloading procedures which is updated annually.  



A process hazards analysis (PHA) has been conducted on the process from truck delivery to reactor operation and finished product. Written operating procedures are in place to ensure ongoing integrity of the process equipment and piping. Inspections include ultrasound thickness tests and visual inspection of glasslined reactors. Leaking pumps, lines and valves are tagged and repaired by maintenance in a timely manner.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
Sulfur Dioxide Process



The sulfur dioxide neutralization process is a batch process in which amines are neutralized with the sulfur dioxide (SO2) in a pressure vessel (reactor). The sulfur dioxide flow to the reactors is controlled so that the majority of the sulfur dioxide is reacted.  Any excess SO2 remaining after the reaction is consumed by the plant scrubber system. The plant thermal oxidizer system suppresses emission of SO2 to the atmosphere. Nitrogen (N2) is used to purge the SO2 delivery lines from the storage vessel to the reactor.



Sulfur dioxide is stored onsite in a 250 psig rated pressure vessel. The sulfur dioxide tank is equipped with pressure relief valve, all outlets on the tank have an excess flow valve combination, and there is an excess flow valve on the line to the plant.   Check valves are also installed at the reactor to prevent backflow of potential contaminants to the storage vessel.  The sulfur dioxide tank is equipped with a high and high high level alarm.  The tank is inspected by a third party for external once every five years and internal once every ten years.  



The SO2 storage tank is loaded from a delivery truck by the use of a closed loop compressed vapor system between the storage tank and the delivery truck to prevent emissions of SO2 to the atmosphere. Plant process operators, supervisors, and delivery truck drivers have been formally trained in the safe handling and loading/unloading of SO2. Operator training is conducted on a yearly basis. A process hazard analysis (PHA) has been conducted on the SO2 storage and batch reaction systems.  Perimeter monitoring alarms are installed on all four sides of the tank.



A process hazards analysis (PHA) has been conducted on the process from truck delivery to reactor operation and finished product. Written operating procedures are in place to ensure ongoing integrity of the process equipment and piping. Inspections include ultrasound thickness tests and visual inspection of glasslined reactor. Leaking pumps, lines and valves are tagged and repaired by maintenance in a timely manner.



Historically the Plant had a SO2 bisulfite process, however this is no longer performed onsite per MOC#  GM-ODE-2013-P-3165.



The maximum volume of sulfur dioxide in the pressurized tank is reduced to approximately 65% of the tank volume capacity  by using administrative controls (procedures) and engineering controls (high and high high level alarms).  The high level is set at 58% tank volume capacity and high high level is set at 65% tank volume capacity.  Documentation is available to verify that the site has not exceeded 65% volume of sulfur dioxide in the tank for over 2 years.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source. 



Champion Technologies is committed to being a responsible member of any community in which it operates in by giving top priority to operating in a safe and environmentally sound manner.  The three core polices, safety, environmental, and sustainability, all state the company's commitment to providing the resources, processes, facilities, standard training, discipline and work culture to ensure a safe work environment for all employees, safety for the communities in which we operate, safe competitive products for our customers.  Champion Technologies employees are committed to being supportive members of the communities in which we operate by integrating economic, social, and environmental considerations into day to day business and long range planning.  The Accidental Release Prevention Programs at the Plant includes daily toolbox meetings, weekly safety meeting for all employees, and Plant safety committee with representation from each department.  The Plant performs annual emergency response training and all employees participate in fire suppression training where each employee is required to use a fire extinguisher to put out a live fire.  Champion Technologies provides a safety and environmental handbook for all new hires which covers general safety and environmental best practices.  In addition, the Odessa Plant hosts / participates in an annual emergency response drill with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and is an active participant in the Ector County Community Advisory Panel (ECAP).    



2.    The stationary source and regulated substances handled. 



Champion Technologies' Odessa Plant is a chemical manufacturing plant located at 115 Proctor Avenue, Odessa, Texas.  The manufacturing plant is a batch chemical processing facility which produces industrial organic chemicals used primarily in the oil and gas industry exploration and production indus

try.  The plant is staffed 24 hours a day, 7 days a week year round and has full time security personnel.  There are two RMP-regulated processes at the facility, with the process boundaries defined consistent with the provisions of 40 CFR Part 68.



The two RMP-regulated toxic substances used in the production of Champion's products are ammonia and sulfur dioxide.  The plant uses these regulated substances and other raw organic and inorganic materials to create products used in multiple applications in the oil and gas industry.  The bulk of materials produced at the Odessa Plant are either oil soluble or water soluble intermediates and products (blends).  Raw materials are received by rail car, bulk cargo tank truck, and in drums and totes.  Finished products are shipped via rail car, bulk cargo tank truck, and in drums and totes.  The raw materials other than ammonia and sulfur dioxide are either not RMP-regulated substances, or present in the processes in quantities that do not trigger RMP applicability.



3.    A Hazard Assessment for the process was completed consistent with the 40 CFR 68, Subpart B 

requirements.  The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances were determined for each reported scenario.



4.    The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps. 

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Odessa Plant facility. Processes at the facility are regulated by both EPA RMP regulation and OSHA PSM standard.  The plant PSM program incorporates all of the PSM elements identified in the regulation.  



4.1 Employee Participation

The Odessa Plant encourages employees to participate in all facets of risk management and accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation include updating and compiling procedures, participating as members of audit teams, participati

ng as members of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) team, incident investigations/corrective actions, plant safety committee, and daily toolbox/weekly safety meetings.  Employees have access to all information created either by hardcopy or electronically on the company SharePoint site.  A culture that drives towards zero accidents and incidents is the focus of Champion Technologies' Safety, Health, and Environment Polices.  In addition, the Odessa Plant has a number of initiatives that address process failures, process safety and employee safety issues.  These initiatives include forming teams including: HAZOPS, Process Improvement Team, and the Safety Committee. In addition, a hazard reporting system is place to identify, report, and track employee reports on near misses.  Each near miss is discussed in the morning meeting Monday - Friday with corrective actions assigned and documented in the system.  



4.2 Process Safety Information

The Odessa Plant keeps a variety of technical documents and standard operating procedures that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Specific departments within the facility are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.



Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). This information addresses any known hazards associated with the use and handling of chemicals. The facility ensures that processes are maintained within operating limits using process controls, monitoring instruments, and highly trained personnel.



The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information incl

udes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written operational procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in each process is not compromised.



4.3 Process Hazard Analysis

The Odessa Plant has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  The Odessa Plant predominately uses the Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) technique to perform Process Hazard Analysis (PHA). The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary. 



The PHA team findings are forwarded to management for review. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive attention first. All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.



To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the Odessa Plant periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 year

s and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained. Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.



4.4 Operating Procedures

The Odessa Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process.  The procedures clearly state operating limits, consequences for deviation, and appropriate responses for deviation.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary. These procedures are reviewed and certified annually as current and accurate. The operating procedures are available in the company intranet (SharePoint) and a hard copy of the procedures that is updated quarterly is also available in case of power outage on a thumb drive.  



4.5 Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Odessa Plant has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in facility operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own before they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at a competent level. All of this training is documented for ea

ch operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.



4.6 Contractors

The Odessa Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work. In addition, contractors are evaluated with respect to their existing programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. High risk contractors are periodically monitored to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.



4.7 Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

The Odessa Plant conducts a PSSR for any new plant modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides an additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented. 



4.8 Mechanical Integrity

The Odessa Pl

ant has well-established practices and procedures in place to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a program that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.



Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. The Odessa Plant incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper material and spare parts are used when repairs are made. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or a Management of Change (MOC) team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.



4.9 Safe Work Practices

The Odessa Plant has four core safe work permit practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. The four permit practices include (1) General Permit to control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure/permit (LOTO) to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance which also includes reference to the line break procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened (3) a procedure/permit to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work), and (4) a permit and procedur

e to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.



4.10 Management of Changes

The Odessa Plant has a system to manage changes to processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process-operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before implementation. Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, equipment information, and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.



4.11    Incident Investigation

The Odessa Plant promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion or toxic gas release that could lead to personal injury, severe environmental impact, or major property damage. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be

reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations. 



4.12 Compliance Audits

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Odessa Plant facility periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years. Both hourly and management personnel participate as audit team members. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained. 



5.    The five-year accident history. 



The facility has not experienced any reportable accidents in the past 5 years.



6.    The emergency response program. 



Champion has implemented a written Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to plan/respond to accidental releases of hazardous materials, fires, natural disasters, and/or acts of terrorism.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response from initial discovery, defensive maneuver that can reduce the severity/extent of the spill/release if can be done without risking injury or exposure to personnel, response to spills/releases, plant alarms, emergency reporting, and evaluation/accountability.  Core site leadership team members have completed Incident Command System (ICS) training to coordinate response efforts with first responders.  A draft organizational chart and key ICS forms are also included in the EAP. 



Employees receive annual training in emergency procedures.  In addition, all employees attend annual fire training which includes both a field exercise where each employee extinguishes a live fire and either classroom or computer based training.  To ensure proper functioning, emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the pl

an is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within processes that would require a modified emergency response. 



The emergency plan has been coordinated with first responders.  The EAP was most recently sent to first responders on April 1, 2013.  In addition, the Plant hosts / participates in an annual onsite emergency response drill with the LEPC.  In 2012, more than 25 first responders attended the annual drill.   



7.    Planned changes to improve safety. 



Studies associated with prevention program elements such as PHAs, incident investigation, management of change, and compliance audits are regularly conducted at Odessa Plant to verify designs and to identify potential hazards.  Recommendations may be developed as a result of these studies and as a result of equipment inspections, safety meetings, review of industry experience, technology improvements, and employee suggestions.  Once formulated, recommendations are reviewed, corresponding action items are developed to implement each recommendation, and then tracked to completion.  

For the ammonia and sulfur dioxide tanks, the following plans that have been identified and based upon risk ranking identified in the PHA, will be completed between June 2013 and end of 2014:



+  Have ammonia and sulfur dioxide suppliers certify compliance with appropriate RAGAGEP for design, installation, and maintenance of the tank truck safeguards.



+  Install ammonia and sulfur dioxide detection with alarms to allow for timely detection of leaks and/or releases.



+  Continue contact with the Odessa LEPC with respect to timely implementation of a call down system for community notification of emergency releases.



+  Install a high-level alarm for the sulfur dioxide tank.



+  Review the gasket materials used in sulfur dioxide service to determine if these are appropriate for the service, and determine if additional measures such as flange covers are needed to address moisture infiltration into
the flange system allowing corrosion effects.
